thread.title: Link with rap superstars helps Washington company double its workforce
thread.title_full: Link with rap superstars helps Washington company double its workforce

author: Graeme Whitfield
title: Link with rap superstars helps Washington company double its workforce
text:
Link with rap superstars helps Washington company double its workforce Clothing firm Woven Inc has increased turnover by 40% after winning work with an American music label Share Rapper Schoolboy Q wearing Woven clothing (Photo: Holland PR) Share Get business   
A surge in sales helped by some of the biggest names in American music has helped a Sunderland clothing company double its workforce and break the £1m turnover barrier. 
Washington-based Woven Inc has increased its annual turnover by 40% in 2016 to £1.1m amid growing global orders and significant investment at its HQ. 
The company provides screen printing, embroidery, transfers and garment finishing in several sectors, including workwear, fashion and sports. 
It also works extensively in the music industry, most recently winning a contract with Top Dawg Entertainment – a record label affiliated with rapper Dr Dre. 
This has seen the company supply merchandise for tours of some the world’s biggest hip-hop stars, including Schoolboy Q and Kendrick Lamar, most recently shipping an order for 5,000 garments for Schoolboy Q’s European tour. Sarah Taylor, Woven Inc; Cllr Harry Trueman, Sunderland City Council; Darren Bosi, Woven Inc; Ian Taylor, Woven Inc (Photo: Holland PR) 
Among other artists Woven has worked with is singer and Strictly Come Dancing contestant Anastasia, whose tour manager recommended the firm to Top Dawg. 
Woven also believes it has benefited from the political uncertainty of Brexit and the American presidential campaign, which has created volatility in the clothing market and prompted a number of US customers to buy merchandise for European events here, rather than having them exported from the US. 
Ian Taylor, who launched the company with his wife Sarah in 2012, had previously worked in extreme sports. 
The company is based on the Pattinsons Industrial Estate and has recently invested £150,000 in new equipment to increase its capacity. It also launched a new website and doubled its headcount from 10 to 20 employees during the year. 
Mr Taylor said: “We’re continuing to make strides in securing new workwear business and are working with some fantastic fashion brands on a national basis. Read More North East firms could see a 10% business rates cut, Communities Secretary Sajid Javid has announced 
“Our reputation is developing here and in the States, and we have the capacity to meet growing demand. Recent investment means we now have the ability to embroider or print 50,000 items of clothing per week.” 
Woven’s growth has been supported by Sunderland City Council , which provides advice and guidance to businesses and helps them access the funding needed to expand. 
The council’s deputy leader Harry Trueman said: “Woven’s ongoing success in the UK and abroad is a fantastic advert for the skills and entrepreneurial spirit of our region. It is an ambitious, young company with huge potential and we’re delighted that it continues to prosper here in Sunderland. We look forward to supporting it in the future.” 
In 2015 Woven doubled the size of its Washington base after securing access to the Regional Growth Fund. In the same year it landed a global contract with Hamleys toy store. Like us on Facebook
